title: Ticket #7093: Refactor/merge Scheduler:: and ResMgr:: try_token_request()
description:
It's unclear where the common code belongs, but the Scheduler::try_token_request() and ResMgre::try_token_request() functions are very similar and should probably be merged to reduce future technical burden.

It seems like DaemonCore might be a good place to put this function (although the decision about when to call it and with which arguments will have to remain daemon-specific).
remarks:
2019-Jun-20 08:53:50 by bbockelm:
Additional refactoring requested from #7094:

  • Add a callback for failure so we can convert the detection of authorization failures to use non-blocking mechanisms.
  • Right now, an empty identity indicates to use the default. We should add an explicit define so it is obvious in the future (as opposed to looking like a programmer oversight).

2019-Jun-20 09:29:18 by bbockelm:
Another thing to investigate here --

Currently, DC_FINISH_TOKEN_REQUEST requires encryption as we're not going to send a token back in the clear! Auto-approval mode, where we trust the network explicitly, doesn't use this RPC.

However, if we use DaemonCore's "force authentication" feature, it refuses to the RPC for users that are authenticated-but-unmapped. It seems we want a slight twist on this -- force authentication but do not require the user to be mapped.

2019-Jul-14 20:36:43 by bbockelm:
Ok, with 3 days left to go before the code freeze...

Here's the PR for the refactor:

https://github.com/htcondor/htcondor/pull/63

It not only gives the startd and schedd a common implementation of the token request workflow (improvement: both now support collector lists correctly!) but also switches everything to non-blocking.

The nonblocking piece is useful in itself, but it also solves some memory management issues (as the SecMan which invokes the callback knows the socket is still valid).

2019-Jul-15 16:34:09 by tlmiller:
Code Review

Added two-subtickets for future work. Otherwise, OK.

2019-Jul-15 16:48:37 by tlmiller:
On second thought, this is all internal code-cleanup and should have no user-visible effects. Brian, if you agree, please just go ahead and mark the ticket resolved.

2019-Jul-15 16:50:33 by bbockelm:
Yup, agreed!

Thanks for the "review under pressure". Much appreciated!
